text:
Privacy Policy Business • China has lost $1 trillion in foreign exchange reserves over three years. What effect does that have on the global economy? • German automakers are striving to keep up with challenges from Silicon Valley, including autonomous driving, electric cars and ride-hailing apps. At stake is the fate of their country’s economy, Europe’s largest. • A group of Republican elder statesmen has called a tax on carbon emissions the fairest way to address global warming. The idea has been billed as “ a conservative climate solution .” • U.S. stocks were up on Tuesday. Here’s a snapshot of global markets . Market Snapshot View Full Overview Smarter Living • Slow down for a moment with your morning coffee or tea, and try to be a little more mindful . • After an unplanned pregnancy , a 25-year-old struggled to be the mother she wanted to be. After going back to school, she’s well on her way . • Recipe of the day : For a meatless midweek dinner, try risotto with smoked mozzarella . Noteworthy • Best of late-night TV. We’re trying out a new feature this week: a rundown of the funniest and most memorable moments from the comedy shows. John Oliver Doesn't Think He'll Get Deported, But He's Being Cautious Video by The Late Show with Stephen Colbert Last night on “The Late Show with Stephen Colbert,” John Oliver lashed out at Mr. Trump for not having “sacrificed” the way some Iraqis and Afghans trying to come to the U.S. have. The pair also took a lighter tour through rural England. 
Advertisement Continue reading the main story • A last refuge for humanity. Great Bear Lake straddles the Arctic Circle in Canada and is home to the first Unesco Biosphere Reserve led by an indigenous community. Residents view the role as crucial to preserving not just their way of life but also the “ survival of the human species ,” our writer says. And in Antarctica, a rift in a massive ice shelf grew about 17 miles in two months. A full break could occur in a few months and create one of the largest icebergs ever recorded . • Broadway’s bathroom problem. Record audiences at theaters have highlighted a major inconvenience at many grand but geriatric buildings: the lack of toilets, particularly for women. Venues are scrambling to add facilities . • Streaking to survive. A newly discovered gecko has a freaky way of escaping predators : When snatched by an attacker, it rips off its scales and skin so that it can slip away unscathed. “It looks like a fish until you grab it, and then it looks like a naked chicken breast,” one researcher said. • Former President Barack Obama has a new hobby. He’s been learning to kitesurf . Back Story Former President Yahya Jammeh of Gambia once pledged that he would reign for a billion years. But last month, he went into exile , 22 years after taking power in a coup. His democratically elected successor has since accused Mr. Jammeh of plundering the treasury and fleeing with millions of dollars. Photo Yahya Jammeh first took power in Gambia in a coup in 1994. He is now in exile in Equatorial Guinea. Credit Thierry Gouegnon/Reuters A lesser-known source of income for Mr. Jammeh, though, had been a head-spinning scheme. For years, his government sold residence permits — sometimes costing up to $15,000 apiece — to thousands of Chinese millionaires. 
Advertisement Why? A special program meant to encourage investment in Hong Kong allowed wealthy Chinese citizens to gain the right to live there if they had permanent residence in another country. As of 2013, about 9,000 Chinese obtained residence permits for Gambia. The maneuvering went on until 2015, when Hong Kong suspended the program. A review found that many of those who enrolled didn’t settle in Hong Kong. Instead, they used their Hong Kong passports for easier travel to other countries (but probably not to Gambia). Patrick Boehler contributed reporting. Photographs may appear out of order for some readers. Viewing this version of the briefing should help.
